title.narrative: 1.2. DISTRICT-LEVEL CAPACITY STRENGTHENING

description.narrative: Subnational institutions and systems in 14 targeted high-burden districts have strengthened capacities to deliver evidence-based MNCH, HIV/AIDS and nutrition care and services for children in a coordinated manner., which contributes to Cross-Sectoral - Social And Behaviour Change, Fast-Track The End Of Hiv/Aids, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being, Nutrition In Early Childhood, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Data, Research, Evaluation And Knowledge Management, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Girls and boys, including the most deprived, receive an integrated package of quality and equitable maternal, neonatal and child health (MNCH), HIV/AIDS and nutrition care and services.

participating-org.narrative: CENTRE FOR RURAL HEALTH UNIVERSITY OF KWAZULU NATAL

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Subnational institutions and systems in 14 targeted high-burden districts have strengthened capacities to deliver evidence-basedMNCH, HIV/AIDS and nutrition care and services for children in a coordinated manner.

description.narrative: There is universal availability of PMTCT services at eligible health facilities, and 95% per cent of pregnant women living with HIV access antiretroviral medicine, preventing 53,000 new HIV infections among newborns. The evolving COVID-19 pandemic continues to disrupt the provision of essential child health and routine immunization services, child nutrition services, and paediatric HIV programmes. Advocacy work that UNICEF has been involved both at national and provincial level seek to address the 51% of all new HIV infections occurring amongst young women aged between 15 to 24 years, as well as the 69% of MTCT occurring through breastfeeding transmission. ; | Status:On-track | As-of Date:05/01/2022
